|Rank=A
|Title=Know the clinical signs of shock
|Description=Recognise arterial hypotension and know how to look for signs of organ failure, know how to look for hyperlactataemia.
|Rubric=Positive diagnosis
|Contributors=Julien Poissy
|Order=4}}

The diagnosis of shock is clinical and is based on the following elements:

1°) arterial hypotension, defined as :

- PAS<90 mmHg

- MAP<65 mmHg

- Variation of more than 30% in chronically hypertensive patients

/Blood pressure may be normal in the initial phase of shock, even though cellular damage has already begun. Importance of lactataemia +++

/Tachycardia precedes arterial hypotension in haemorrhagic shock and hypovolaemic shock. This is a clinical point of attention.

2°) signs of peripheral hypoperfusion :

- Asthenia

- Marbling, particularly on the knees. Correlated with gravity

- Polypnoea >22 cycles/min

- Skin recolouration time > 3s

- Confusion, agitation

- Oliguria

question.title: What is a characteristic of shock that may be present in the initial phase, despite normal blood pressure readings?
question.description: Blood pressure may be normal in the initial phase of shock, even though cellular damage has already begun. What is this characteristic?

option_a.title: Hypertension
option_a.description: Elevated blood pressure is a common symptom of shock

option_b.title: Tachycardia
option_b.description: A rapid heart rate is often present in shock

option_c.title: Lactataemia
option_c.description: Elevated lactate levels are a hallmark of shock

option_d.title: Arterial hypotension
option_d.description: Low blood pressure is a defining characteristic of shock

correct_option.title: Lactataemia
correct_option.description: This consists only a letter of the correct option
